;将工人输入香港以缓解劳动力紧缩不会给老板任何激励周五，该市各部门的工会警告说，要提高当地雇员的工资和福利。

;

;工人团体再次反对拟议的计划，发展部长早些时候将其描述为“不可避免的”。当地媒体机构报道称，当局旨在通过一项针对建筑、运输和航空行业的特殊计划引进约 9,000 名工人。

;

;在政府最早于下个月就此问题定下基调之前，工会

;

;机场空运雇员协会总干事朱汉忠周五表示，机场前线员工，包括飞机清洁工和行李员处理人员的基本工资已经很低，介于 13,000 港元和 16,000 港元（2,000 美元）之间，并且不得不依靠加班来维持生计。

;

;非常有吸引力，”楚在一个广播节目中说。 “为低收入工作输入劳动力将对当地工人造成打击……雇主会不会没有动力增加当地人的工资和福利？”

;

;他说，应该提高当地工人的福利增加人力和恢复航班交通的方式，目前是大流行前水平的 60%。

;

;香港公司努力应对 20% 的离职率，商业团体表示

;

;发展局局长 Bernadette Linn Hon-ho 周四在接受媒体采访时表示，随着大量住房和基础设施项目的涌现，该市的建筑业将进入高峰期，因此引进外劳是“不可避免的”。

;

;据其他媒体机构援引未经证实的消息来源称，政府计划根据一项特别计划引进外劳，从事一些工作，包括钢筋弯曲和脚手架、驾驶小巴和机场前线操作。

;

;工会猛烈抨击当局绕过劳工咨询委员会，该机构在政府做出最终决定之前推荐外国劳工进口申请。

;

;目前，进口劳工平均需要五个月的时间。雇主可以提交申请并证明当地没有合适的候选人。提交的意见随后由董事会审议并提交给政府。

;

;随着贫富差距的扩大，新的最低工资仍然无法满足在职穷人的需求

;

;周五，Chan Fung-yuen，汽车运输业总工会公共小巴分会也提出外来司机带来的安全问题，他们习惯了不同的路况，例如内地的左舵驾驶习惯和比香港多的车道。

;

;“香港有很多人。交通繁忙，有很多红绿灯。他们可能无法适应紧凑的生活节奏，”Chan 在同一个广播节目中警告说。

;

;他敦促改善当地司机的工资和工作条件，以缓解紧张局势。

;

;但小巴公司 Kellis 的营运总监陈志辉表示，提高司机的薪金并不能缓解人手短缺的问题，因为有些人选择减少工作时间以获得政府补贴。

;

;要获得根据长者生活津贴计划，政府每月提供4,060港元的福利援助，一对65岁或以上的夫妇每月最多只能赚取16,080港元。

;

;陈说，即使公司提供高达本地司机每小时 90 港元。他表示，他宁愿输入工人以确保服务，尽管必须提供员工宿舍会产生更高的运营成本。

;

;香港劳动力下降创纪录，2022 年有 94,000 名工人称其退出

;

;“雇用这样的工人可以确保我们的小巴服务的连续性，并为居民服务，”陈说。

;

;他补充说，他更愿意从靠近香港的内地城市招聘司机，因为他们会说广东话，而住在边境附近的人下班后可以回家。

;

;陈还表示，小巴运营商将根据政府指示提供培训。

;俄罗斯总统弗拉基米尔普京的一位顶级盟友表示，乌克兰战争可能会持续数十年，

;

;俄罗斯 RIA 通讯社称，普京强大的安全委员会副主席、前总统德米特里·梅德韦杰夫在访问越南期间发表了讲话。

;

;梅德韦杰夫经常发表强硬评论，上个月将乌克兰当局描述为感染者。

;

;“这场冲突将持续很长时间，很可能持续数十年，”RIA 周四援引梅德韦杰夫的话说。

;

;“只要有这样的权力，就会有，比方说，三年休战，两年冲突，一切都会重演，”他继续说道，并重申了莫斯科关于乌克兰是纳粹国家的说法

;

;梅德韦杰夫再次提出核冲突的可能性，称如果西方向乌克兰提供核武器，俄罗斯将不得不发动先发制人的打击。 1 月，梅德韦杰夫表示，如果俄罗斯被击败，可能会引发核战争。

;

;中国和平特使再次告诉北京必须推动莫斯科结束对乌克兰的入侵

;

;“战争法则不可逆转.如果涉及核武器，就必须先发制人，”俄罗斯新闻机构周五援引梅德韦杰夫的话说。

;

;梅德韦杰夫的声明是在白俄罗斯领导人亚历山大·卢卡申科周四表示俄罗斯已经开始将核武器转移到其与欧盟接壤的领土。

;

;3 月，普京表示他将在白俄罗斯部署“战术”核武器——实际上是短程原子导弹，这引起了白俄罗斯的谴责

;

;与此同时，在华盛顿，美国高级军官马克·米莱将军表示，俄罗斯不会在乌克兰取得军事胜利，同时还警告称，基辅不太可能很快将莫斯科的所有军队赶出。

; p>;

;“从军事上来说，这场战争不会由俄罗斯赢得。周四，在支持乌克兰的数十个国家举行的虚拟会议结束后，米利告诉记者。

;

;俄罗斯最初的战略目标，包括推翻基辅政府，“在军事上无法实现，参谋长联席会议主席米利说。

;

;米利和梅德韦杰夫的评论强​​调了乌克兰战争将持续下去的预测，双方都没有双方准备赢得明确的胜利，目前没有谈判。

;

;与此同时，乌克兰有数十万俄罗斯士兵，这使得基辅收复其所有领土的目标不太可能“在短期内，”Milley 说。

;

;“这意味着战斗将继续，这将是血腥的，这将是艰难的。在某个时候，双方要么通过谈判达成和解，要么达成军事结论。”

;

;美国带头推动国际社会支持乌克兰，迅速组建联盟支持基辅在俄罗斯于 2022 年 2 月入侵并协调来自数十个国家的援助之后。

;

;乌克兰战争：入侵别尔哥罗德可能会拉长俄罗斯的防御

;

;乌克兰的支持者总共提供了近 650 亿美元的安全保障美国国防部长劳埃德·奥斯汀表示，该国将向乌克兰提供援助。

;

;奥斯汀表示，欧洲盟国正在制定一项协调计划，以在 F-16 战斗机上训练乌克兰军队，但五角大楼领导人警告说，这将是一次代价高昂且复杂的任务，不会成为解决战争的灵丹妙药。

;

;奥斯汀说，盟国认识到，除了训练之外，乌克兰还需要能够维持和维护飞机，并拥有足够的飞机

;

;他说，防空系统仍然是乌克兰在控制空域的更广泛努力中最需要的武器。

;

;“没有魔法武器，”米利说，他在五角大楼与奥斯汀一起讲话。他说，提供 10 架 F-16 可能耗资 20 亿美元，包括维护费用。

;

;“俄罗斯人拥有一千架第四代和第五代战斗机，所以如果你要在空中与俄罗斯较量，你将需要大量的第四代和第五代战斗机。”

;

;因此，他说，盟国首先向乌克兰提供大量综合防空系统以进行掩护，这是正确的做法

;

;他说，F-16 未来将成为乌克兰空中力量的一部分，但“需要相当长的时间才能建立一支规模、范围和规模都符合要求的空军”

;

;奥斯汀说，荷兰和丹麦的国防部长正在与美国合作开展这项工作，挪威、比利时、葡萄牙和波兰已经表示愿意为培训做出贡献。此外，他说盟国将设立一个基金，以便其他国家可以为整体努力做出贡献。

;

;西方专家说，俄罗斯声称的巴赫穆特胜利根本不是什么

;

;在地面上，俄罗斯瓦格纳雇佣军组织叶夫根尼·普里戈任 (Yevgeny Prigozhin) 的负责人周四表示，他的部队已开始将他们在乌克兰东部的热点城市巴赫穆特 (Bakhmut) 的阵地移交给俄罗斯军方。

;

;瓦格纳表示，它开始撤出其在声称已在周末完全占领被摧毁的城市后，武装分子继续战斗。

;

;乌克兰否认巴赫穆特已落入俄罗斯手中，坚称其仍控制着该市的一个“微区”，并表示仍在推进

;

;巴赫穆特之战已经进行了将近一年，将这座城市夷为平地，并摧毁了领导俄罗斯进攻工业中心的瓦格纳新兵。

;

;中国计划于周日发射其 C919 窄体喷气式飞机的首次商业飞行，标志着北京推动打破波音和空中客车在全球飞机生产领域的双头垄断的一个备受期待的里程碑。

;

;上午 10 点 45 分，由中国东方航空公司运营的航班号 MU9191 的首航将启程从上海到北京——中国最繁忙的国内航线。根据航空公司的时间表，这架飞机预计将于下午 1 点 10 分降落在北京首都机场。

;

;下午晚些时候，它将返回上海，航班号为 MU9192。截至周五下午，这些旅行似乎还没有开放供公众预订。

;

;中国航空市场在经历了三年多的 Covid-19 爆发后最近几个月重新开放，这导致了许多机场关闭以及国内和国际航班取消。根据飞行数据和分析公司 OAG 的数据，尽管国际航班的速度较慢，但​​国内航班此后一直在恢复。

;

;什么是中国的 C919 客机，它可以与空中客车竞争，波音？

;

;根据 OAG 的数据，从北京首都国际机场到上海虹桥国际机场的航线仍然是中国最繁忙的国内航线。不过，OAG 表示，与 2019 年疫情前相比，广州白园机场至上海虹桥航线的座位容量增长速度更快。

;

;由国有企业建造的国产 C919中国商用飞机有限责任公司 (Comac) 与波音 737 和空中客车 A320 系列飞机竞争，经过 14 年多的发展，于 9 月获得了中国民用航空局 (CAAC) 的认证。

;

;这架客机于 12 月交付给中国东方航空公司，当时中国航空公司开始进行总计 100 小时的试飞。据中国官方媒体报道，预计商业航班将于 2023 年上半年开始。

;

;中国在商业航空市场雄心勃勃，中央政府制定了 C919 获得 10 架飞机的计划到 2025 年占国内市场份额的 %。

;

;据官方媒体中央电视台 1 月份的报道，中国商飞表示已收到 1,200 多架 C919 订单。

;

;航空业受中美关系恶化负面影响的高科技行业。美国航空航天公司波音公司的中国业务一直与北京和华盛顿之间的恶化关系纠缠在一起。其 737 MAX 在印度尼西亚和埃塞俄比亚发生两起致命事故后在中国停飞了四年多，直到 1 月份才刚刚恢复运营。

;

;中国东方航空公司周四表示，C919 将投入使用“近期实际运营”，上海是其商业运营的主要基地。

;

;1998 年 5 月骚乱爆发时，印度尼西亚作家和主要女权主义者 Julia Suryakusuma 在雅加达首都陷入混乱，暴徒袭击和抢劫拥有印尼华人的企业。

;

;在军事独裁者苏哈托统治 32 年后，印尼人猛烈起来抗议粮食短缺、大规模失业、腐败和经济危机，以及少数华人社区——长期受到歧视性政策的攻击并被指责偷工作——受到攻击。

;随着印度尼西亚纪念 1998 年 5 月导致苏哈托下台的骚乱 25 周年，围绕着印尼华人妇女的性侵事件仍未被公开。

;

;但全国的实际数字可能要高得多，因为骚乱也Suryakusuma 说，印尼其他主要城市也爆发了疫情。

;

;“并非所有受害者都选择挺身而出。羞耻、屈辱以及自我价值和尊严的完全丧失常常导致强奸受害者埋葬对恐怖和创伤的回忆。”

;

;

;“我们举着标语从雅加达的国家纪念碑游行到国防部大楼，向路人分发小册子并要求见部长，”她说。

;

;抗议者要求会见当时的印度尼西亚武装部队国防部长兼指挥官 Wiranto 将军的请求被拒绝，但他们被允许提交一份请愿书，要求举行军方对其在 5 月骚乱中的作用负责。

;

;“第一手资料表明，军事特工挑衅者在现场煽动暴徒骚乱并袭击中资商店，”Suryakusuma 说。

;

; p>;

;“暴乱者大多对苏哈托和为他的政权服务的印尼华人大亨感到愤怒，但他们受到的保护太严密，因此无法触及，”她说。

;

;相反，暴徒被军方特工将他们的挫败感发泄在普通中产阶级印尼华人及其女性亲属等“简单目标”身上。

;

;之后被杀。在骚乱中被强奸的八名妇女中有七名随后被谋杀，”她补充道。

;

;印度尼西亚的 Reformasi 改革 25 年后，佐科威领导下的民主正在瓦解吗？

;

;但悲剧也变成了Suryakusuma 说，这是变革的催化剂。 1998 年对印尼华人妇女犯下的恐怖事件统一并激发了沿“世俗”和“穆斯林”路线两极分化的妇女权利团体。

;

;在骚乱发生后的同年，印度尼西亚还成立了全国暴力侵害妇女委员会 (KOMNAS Perempuan) 与政府合作并就打击基于性别的暴力向政府提出建议。

;

;今年早些时候，总统佐科·维多多正式“承认”1998 年 5 月的骚乱，以及其他 11 次事件，被认为是“严重侵犯人权”，他也对此表示“遗憾”。

;

;Suryakusuma 表示，她希望维多多的声明将导致采取更具体的和解步骤。 “但如果不揭露军方在五月骚乱中参与的真实程度，就不可能发生这种情况；谁是主谋，谁是执行命令的人。”

;

;维多多的姿态也未能令民间社会团体满意，国际特赦组织印度尼西亚执行主任乌斯曼·哈米德表示，它必须超越口头承诺。< /p>;

;“公开点名几起悲惨事件是远远不够的。总统甚至没有谈论 1998 年 5 月骚乱中系统性发生的性暴力，”他说。

;

;

; 1998 年 5 月的骚乱有力地提醒我们，印度尼西亚的妇女权利还有很长的路要走。

;“回到 1980 年代，我是第一个公开承认自己是女权主义者的女性。许多人对这个词过敏，”朱莉娅的圣战 (Julia's Jihad)、国家伊布主义 (State Ibuism) 和性、权力与国家 (Sex, Power and Nation) 等书的作者说。

;

;她承认，随着印度尼西亚人越来越多地转向宗教保守主义，女权主义如今面临着相当大的挑战。

;

; p>;

;“女权主义在某种程度上已经成为一个肮脏的词。有时给自己贴上女权主义者的标签会导致强烈反对，尽管我现在改变我的想法已经太迟了，”Suryakusuma 说。

;在当地媒体 Tirto 于 2021 年对 1,500 名男性和女性受访者进行的一项民意调查中，51 % 的女性受访者认为自己是女权主义者，但从未参加过行动主义。另有 35% 的人希望与这个词保持距离。

;

;尽管对女权主义的反应冷淡，但印度尼西亚在妇女权利方面继续取得进展，Suryakusuma 说。

;

;“穆斯林女权主义者，例如来自印度尼西亚妇女乌里玛大会的那些人，现在站在我们斗争的前线，”她说，并补充说，她们在伊斯兰教和妇女权利问题之间充当桥梁的方式给她留下了深刻的印象。

;

;被问到她是否对印尼女权主义的未来充满希望时，她笑着回答：“我今年 69 岁了，我一直告诉人们我想活到 100 岁。如果我悲观，我就不会那样做关于即将发生的事情。”

; Fri, 26 May 2023 11:50:02 +0800 As ‘Blue Helmets’ turn 75, peacekeeping chief laments UN divisionshttps://www.scmp.com/news/world/africa/article/3221883/blue-helmets-turn-75-chief-laments-un-divisions?utm_source=rss_feed
;;2023.05.26 11:41;
;;

;联合国维和行动负责人表示，分裂的安全理事会阻碍了the so-called Blue Helmet forces, which turn 75 on Monday.

;

;Jean-Pierre Lacroix said a long list of countries had benefited from the “millions of men and women who have served under the UN flag” since the forces' creation in 1948.

;

;But he added that paralysis and conflict between the United States, Britain and France on one side and Russia and China on the other was making operations difficult.

;

;“We are suffering from the fact that our member states are divided,” the undersecretary general for UN peace operations said.

;

;The French diplomat, 63, added that the UN was finding it “more difficult to achieve the ultimate objectives of peacekeeping: to deploy, support the implementation of a peace agreement and then gradually leave”.

;

;Although the 15-member council regularly renews the mandates of peacekeeping missions, Lacroix called for more unity so they can better “influence the implementation of peace agreements and political processes”.

;

;Indian peacekeepers among 15 killed in anti-UN protests in Congo's east

;

;May 29 marks the International Day of United Nations Peacekeepers, created in 2002 by the UN General Assembly to honour those who serve in conflict zones.

;

;Because next Monday is the Memorial Day holiday in the United States, the UN celebrated the peacekeepers' 75th anniversary on Thursday, in memory of the “more than 4,200 peacekeepers killed in the cause of peace” since 1948.

;

;Secretary General Antonio Guterres observed a minute's silence for the 103 peacekeepers who died last year.

;

; The UN stabilisation mission in Mali (Minusma), which has 12,000 peacekeepers deployed, has suffered the most fatalities of any mission in recent years. Since its creation in 2013, 185 of its members have died in hostile acts.

;

;More than 87,000 people from 125 countries are presently deployed on 12 peace operations around the world. They include in Lebanon, Mali, the Democratic Republic of Congo, Cyprus, India and Pakistan.

;

;Lacroix noted that the “list of countries that have regained stability is long,” citing Ivory Coast, Liberia, Sierra Leone, Angola and Cambodia in the 1990s and 2000s.

;

;But he argues that “the international community was much more united at the time, and the political processes in these countries were implemented with the active and united support of our member states”.

;

;As for failures, he pointed to the failure of UN peacekeepers to prevent the 1994 Rwanda genocide, which killed at least 800,000 ethnic Tutsis and Hutus, and the 1995 massacre of at least 8,000 mostly Muslim men and boys at Srebrenica during the war in Bosnia, Europe's only acknowledged genocide since the Holocaust during World War II.

;

;The UN's reputation has also been tarnished by numerous allegations that peacekeepers charged with protecting civilians sexually abused women and children, including in Central African Republic and Congo.

;

;Ukraine: Lessons to be learned from Bosnia's Srebrenica, says Dutch PM

;

;Another high-profile blunder was the cholera epidemic in Haiti that began in 2010 after UN peacekeepers introduced the bacteria into the country's largest river by sewage run-off from their base.

;

;Despite that, Richard Gowan, the International Crisis Group's UN director, said “UN peacekeeping has a surprisingly decent track record” and “has done a good job of tamping down crises, protecting civilians and rebuilding broken states in cases from the Suez crisis in the 1950s to Liberia in the 2000s”.

;

;Lacroix pointed to other challenges peacekeepers are facing: more violent and dangerous operating environments and more sophisticated attacks and fake news and disinformation which are “a massive threat to the population and the peacekeepers.”

;

;And old and new drivers of conflict – including transnational criminal activities, trafficking, drugs, weapons, the illegal exploitation of natural resources, and the impact of climate change exacerbating competition between herders and farmers – are also having an “absolutely massive influence”.

;

;The Crisis Group's Gowan said it was pretty clear that the UN is “trapped” in some countries like Mali and Congo where there aren't enough peacekeepers to halt recurring cycles of violence.

;

;Nepalese peacekeepers accused of 'heinous' child rape in South Sudan

;

;Some African governments, including Mali's, are turning to private security providers like Russia's Wagner Group to fight insurgents, he said.

;

;“I think we should be wary of dumping UN operations outright,” Gowan told Associated Press. “我们从阿富汗这样的案例中学到了惨痛的教训，即使是全副武装的西方军队也无法实现和平。 The UN's track record may not be perfect, but nobody else is much better at building stability in turbulent states.”

;

;Additional reporting by Associated Press

; Fri, 26 May 2023 11:50:02 +0800 ‘They peed in my car’: 32-hour ride-sharing car ‘occupation’ by Chinese father and daughter ends with police detentionhttps://www.scmp.com/news/people-culture/trending-china/article/3221395/they-peed-my-car-32-hour-ride-sharing-car-occupation-chinese-father-and-daughter-ends-police?utm_source=rss_feed

;

;Angered by this, Wang decided to end the service and drive them back to where they had originally set off, telling them: “I would rather die than drive you.”

;

;The police were called but failed to persuade the pair to leave the car, so Wang drove them to her residential compound that night and went home leaving the car doors unlocked hoping they would be gone by the next morning.

;

;

;

;

;

;Wang said she was simply “washing her car”.

;Another joked: “What if they also refuse to leave the police station after seven days?”

; Fri, 26 May 2023 11:20:01 +0800 What are China’s ‘secret police stations’ and is their role exaggerated by foreign governments?https://www.scmp.com/news/china/diplomacy/article/3221396/what-are-chinas-secret-police-stations-and-their-role-exaggerated-foreign-governments?utm_source=rss_feed

;;

;Western countries have again called for China's “secret police stations” to be shut down after governments in Europe and North America put the spotlight back on Chinese operations overseas.

;

;On May 15, Germany's foreign ministry said it believed China had continued to operate the “illegal overseas police stations”, despite earlier promises from Beijing it would close what it called “service stations”.

;

;A day earlier, Canadian Public Safety Minister Marco Mendicino said there could be more “secret police stations” operating across the country, months after investigations were launched into two centres in Montreal.

;

;The latest calls come just a month after United States authorities arrested two New York residents of Chinese descent suspected of operating one such station out of a commercial office in Manhattan's Chinatown.

;

;Beijing categorically denies the stations are used for extraterritorial law enforcement or overseas spying, and some analysts say the role of these stations could be exaggerated.

;

;

;

;Starting in September, human rights organisation Safeguard Defenders released reports alleging that China's Ministry of Public Security was operating more than 100 overseas police stations in as many as 53 countries.

;

;The outposts, which have allegedly been operating as far back as 2016, were established by regional police bureaus from cities in southeastern China, such as Fuzhou, Nantong, Wenzhou and Qingtian.

;

;Investigations have found stations operating out of businesses and commercial buildings in areas frequented by Chinese diaspora communities.

;

;Safeguard Defenders said the stations acted as vehicles for the ministry's “persuade to return” operations, which target fugitives living overseas – such as scammers or corrupt businesspeople – to go back to China to face prosecution.

;

;However, the stations have also been linked to the alleged monitoring and threatening of dissidents and pro-democracy activists, including non-Chinese citizens.

;

;Japan urged to root out secret Chinese 'police stations' amid spying concerns

;

;Though not police officers themselves, the outposts' personnel have been accused of using various methods of intimidation, such as online harassment and the coercion of families.

;

;Some Western governments have called the alleged operations “unacceptable” and “outrageous”, accusing Beijing of operating illegal overseas law enforcement, violating international norms and flagrantly interfering in their domestic affairs.

;

;

;

;Beijing has repeatedly denied that the stations are overseas police stations. Instead, it says they are used to provide bureaucratic services such as driving licence renewal.

;

;“The relevant institutions helped overseas Chinese who could not return to China due to the pandemic,” foreign ministry spokesman Wang Wenbin said on May 15, adding that the services provided had since moved online and that the stations had been closed down.

;

;Rather than police officers or government employees, Beijing maintains that the stations were staffed by local volunteers seeking to help their communities. Investigations by authorities in the US and elsewhere have corroborated some of Beijing's assertions.

;

;While China's foreign ministry has said China is cracking down on transnational crimes, it said all operations were in line with international law and that Western allegations to the contrary were “smearing” and “disinformation” based on hearsay.

;

;Telecoms and online fraud have been rampant in China in recent years. In September, China passed a law giving authorities the power to pursue suspects abroad, although the law stipulates it must be done in conjunction with international law enforcement agencies.

;

;Since 2014, China has also engaged in “Operation Fox Hunt”, the state-sanctioned pursuit of suspected financial criminals or those facing corruption charges who have fled the country.

;

;“China always upholds the principle of non-interference in other countries' internal affairs, strictly observes the international law and respects the judicial sovereignty of all countries,” Wang said.

;

;

;

;The most high-profile action taken against these “police stations” was the arrest of New York residents Lu Jianwang, 61, and Chen Jinping, 59, by US authorities on April 17.

;

;They have been charged with “conspiring to act as agents of the PRC government” as well as obstruction of justice for allegedly “destroying evidence” related to correspondence with officials from the Ministry of Public Security. The station they allegedly operated was closed in autumn 2022 after it was searched by US federal agents.

;

;A growing list of other countries, from Britain to Austria, have launched their own investigations or probes into the “police stations” and their alleged criminal activities.

;

;In Canada, police said they were investigating two Chinese community groups who allegedly operated “secret police stations” in Montreal, although later local media reports suggest the groups continued to operate.

;

;The foreign ministries of both Ireland and the Netherlands said they had addressed the matter directly with China's respective ambassadors. There is also mounting domestic pressure in countries such as Japan, where opposition parties are calling on the Japanese governmentto release more information about these stations.

;

;Some countries, including Italy and Serbia, previously established joint patrol partnerships between Chinese police officers and local forces. The programmes were pitched as a way to help with the growing number of Chinese tourists visiting overseas destinations.

;

;However, in December Italy announced it would stop the programme – which had been suspended during the Covid-19 pandemic – in light of the report by Safeguard Defenders.

;

;

;

;Jeremy Daum, a senior fellow at Yale Law School's Paul Tsai China Centre, called the narrative building around these stations a “distraction” from other transnational actions taken by Beijing.

;

;“I believe extraterritorial harassment by Chinese authorities and ultranationalist citizens is a real problem [but] the role of these police stations in that is probably minimal,” Daum said.

;

;Following the initial release of the Safeguard Defenders report, Daum highlighted that the stations operated openly in the communities they were based in and essentially acted as video conference rooms for mediation and other services.

;

;He also noted after the New York arrests that the US Department of Justice presented little connection between the alleged actions of Lu and Chen with the stations themselves.

;

;'Fox hunt': US charges 7 in alleged plot to repatriate US resident to China

;

;Daum said he feared the focus on “overseas police stations” was part of “a growing trend of considering everyone with perceived ties to China, be it by ethnic heritage, business, etc … as a potential agent of the [Chinese Communist Party]”.

;

;Regardless of whether they were used for transnational law enforcement, the controversy was further damaging Beijing's image in the West, said Chong Ja Ian, an associate professor of political science at the National University of Singapore.

;

;“Such alleged action raises doubts about the actuality of [China's] commitment to rule of law and respect for sovereignty despite official statements otherwise,” Chong said. “Even if the outposts are for standard administrative procedures, they still need some sort of registration.”

;

;Chong and Daum both said that ongoing judicial proceedings in places such as the US should “shine more light” on the station's operations.

;

;

;

;On Tuesday, Safeguard Defenders said it had been the target of a “prolonged” disinformation campaign involving tens of thousands of fake social media accounts since the release of the initial report in September.

;

;On YouTube and other websites, thousands of virtually identical videos and blog posts have appeared under a similar name to the group's original report, but they contain a 669-word defence of China's position on the matter.

;

;On Twitter, references to the reports were temporarily banned after a mass of suspected bot accounts triggered the social media site's anti-spam filter.

;

;Twitter's overhaul of its verification scheme allowed thousands of accounts to masquerade as Safeguard Defenders, the group said. While the social media site has reportedly removed as many as 1000 “impostor” accounts, a search by the South China Morning Post showed hundreds of accounts using the same name, profile picture, and bio as Safeguard Defenders remained on the site.

;

;The campaign was “seemingly aimed at drowning out the messaging and online visibility of Safeguard Defenders,” the group said in a press release.

;

;It added that its previous reports on China have triggered similar waves of online harassment, but the group stopped short of calling it a state-coordinated operation.

;

;“There is no way to know whether this campaign has State-backing, but the scale of operation and its uniformity indicates a single body is directing it,” Safeguard Defenders said.
